data.text:
South African Racing

JUMP TO: South African Racecourses South African Feature Races South African Racing Prize Money South African Racing Calendar South African Racing FAQs

South Africa has a long and rich history with horse racing with the first race taking place in the KwaZulu-Natal province in the 1840s. Today it plays host to the biggest race on the calendar in the G1 Durban July at Greyville which was first run in 1897.

Horse racing is regulated by the National Horse Racing Authority, formerly The Jockey Club of South Africa, which was founded in 1882. It aims to ensure that thoroughbred racing is provided with the highest level of integrity.

Horse racing takes place in South Africa 364 days of the year which generates a massive R $7 billion turnover. The two bodies which control racing in South Africa are Phumelela Gaming and Leisure and Gold Circle.

Phumelela was formed in 1997 when horse racing was corporatized in Gauteng to ensure it was competitive as the gambling market was set to grow with the legalization of casinos and a national lottery. They contribute around half the country’s prize money which is generated from tote turnover. All tote betting is commingled into a national pool.

Phumelela is licensed to operate horse racing and tote betting in seven of South Africa’s nine provinces (Free State, Northern Cape, Eastern Cape, and Gauteng) while Golden Circle control horseracing in Kwazulu-Natal which has racecourses Greyville and Scottsville.

Gold Circle was formed in 1996 when the Durban Turf Club, Clairwood Turf Club and Pietermaritzburg Turf Club amalgamated. In 2005, Gold Circle and Phumelela, established the National Racing Bureau to handle the administration of racing to ensure the sport was streamlined in South Africa.

Phumelela, in partnership with Gold Circle, manages Tellytrack which has the exclusive rights to broadcast the vision of racing in South Africa.

The “big three” races on the South Africa calendar are the Durban July at Greyville in July, the Cape Town Met at Kenilworth in January, and the Summer Cup at Turffontein in November.

Leading international trainer Mike de Kock is South Africa’s most successful trainer with 129 Grade 1 winners. He has had much success around the globe including in the UAE, Hong Kong, Singapore, United Kingdom and USA.

He is an eight-time champion trainer in South Africa and won the Summer Cup six times, Durban July four times and Cape Met three times. He claimed another South African Triple Crown in 2021 when Malmoos won the South African Derby.

Top young jockey Luke Ferrais became the youngest jockey to win the South African Triple Crown in 2021 when he teamed up with de Kock and steered Malmoos to victory in the SA Derby.

The most famous jockey to come out of South Africa is Douglas “Durban Demon” Whtye who dominated the Hong Kong racing scene winning the Jockeys’ title 13 years in a row (2001-2013).

South African Racecourses

There are seven racecourses in operation in South Africa which hosts race meetings 364 days a year.

Fairview (Eastern Cape)

Draaifontein Road, Greenbushes, Port Elizabeth

Direction: Clockwise

Fairview racecourse opened in 2007 which boasts a stabling complex and various training tracks and facilities. A new polytrack opened in 2013 which hosts meetings at the Port Elizabeth racecourse.

Racing mainly takes place on Friday and they host 20 Listed races throughout the year including the Port Elizabeth Gold Cup in June.

Arlington which was the other racecourse in Port Elizabeth closed in 2013 after hosting race meetings for 63 years.

Kenilworth (Western Cape)

Rosmead Avenue, Kenilworth, Cape Town

Direction: Anti-clockwise

Kenilworth racecourse is the oldest in the country established in 1881 offering majestic views as it sits at the bottom of the Table Mountain in Cape Town. It is the main track in the Western Cape with eight Grade 1 races run at the track in January and December. The biggest meeting is in late January which features four Grade 1 races including the Cape Met.

Three are three racecourses at Kenilworth with the main one called the “new” track an oval-shaped 2800 metres circumference track with a short straight. The “old” track is oval-shaped and used during autumn and winter months. There is also a short track of 1200 metres. Racing mainly takes place on Wednesday and Saturdays.

Durbanville (Western Cape)

Bowlers Way, Durbanville, Cape Town

Direction: Anti-clockwise

Durbanville racecourse is a unique track with great drainage which makes it a perfect winter racecourse, which is where they host most of their meetings.

The track is 2200 metres in circumference with a run in of approximately 600 metres and a downhill run in the straight to the winning post. Given these features the course can produce some track specialists which tends to favour horses drawn well.

Their biggest race of the year on the program is the Listed Settlers Trophy in late September.

Greyville (Kwazulu-Natal)

150 Avondale Road, Greyville, Durban

Direction: Clockwise

Greyville recourse is one of two tracks in Kwazulu-Natal along with Scottsville which are both controlled by Gold Circle with the naming sponsor Hollywoodbets since 2019. It has also hosted night racing since 1996.

It is a large pear-shaped racecourse with a circumference of 2800 metres; 2400 metres under lights. Given a road passes under the course it has a number of unusual gradients. It is uphill between 2400 metres to 1,800 metres and then slopes downhill for the next 800 metres before uphill for another 500 metres. It features a straight of approximately 500 metres which is flat run to the winning post.

A 2000 metre all-weather Polytrack opened in 2014 which is on the inside of the racecourse. The polytrack is in action every Friday night between September and April.

It is home to Africa’s biggest race and massive event in the Durban July which is a colourful celebration with around 50,000 guests packing the racecourse in early July. They also host a massive race day which features four Grade 1 races in late July headlined by the Champions Cup.

Scottsville (Kwazulu-Natal)

45 New England Road, Pietermaritzburg

Direction: Clockwise

Scottsville racecourse is an oval shaped course with a circumference of 2300 metres and a straight of 550 metres. It also features a 1200 metre straight course.

The track is in the KwaZulu-Natal province and approximately 40 kilometres from Durban. It is controlled by Golden Circle and features a Golden Horse Casino attached to the back of the Grandstand.

They race predominantly on Sunday and host one Grade 1 race which is the Allan Robertson Championship for two-year-olds in early June. Another feature meeting in late June features 2 Grade 2 races in the Track and Ball Derby and the Track and Ball Oaks.

Vaal (Free State)

Ascot Road, Viljoensdrif

Direction: Clockwise

Vaal is a sharp turning track with a large circumference of 2900 metres and boasts the largest straight in the country at 1000 metres.

The straight has a chute for 600 metres creating a straight course of 1600 metres and is home to great sprint races. Racing in Vaal is predominantly mid-week with meetings on Tuesday and Thursday.

Turffontein (Gauteng)

Turf Club Street, Turffontein, Johannesburg

Direction: Clockwise

Turffontein racecourse hosts some of the best racing in the country. It has a long history being founded in 1887 by the Johannesburg Turf Club and features an impressive backdrop of the Johannesburg buildings.

There are two tracks: an inner and an outer track. The main (outer) track has long bends and an incline from the 1200 metres to the final turn into the straight making it a testing course.

Racing is predominantly on a Saturday and features some great Grade 1 races across the year most notably the Summer Cup in late November and the South African Derby in early April.

Feature Races in South Africa

Cape Town Met – Kenilworth (January)

The Cape Town Met (Metropolitan) was first run in 1883 and is a race over 2000 metres under weight-for-age conditions. It’s without doubt Cape Town’s biggest race on the calendar and one of the biggest on the African calendar.

Originally run in November and over 1600 metres it moved to the January slot on the calendar in 1947.

Popular local Pocket Power has won the race an incredible three times (2007,2008,2009).

Another popular winner was Mike de Kock-trained Horse Chestnut (1999) who was South Africa’s first horse to win the Triple Crown (Guineas, Classic and Derby). Rainbow Bridge won the 2021 edition, claiming the race for the second time.

South African Derby – Turffontein (April)

The South African Derby is the premier race for three-year-olds run over 2450 metres at Turffontein. First run in 1907 it is the final leg of the South African Triple Crown.

Malmoos claimed the 2021 race and joined an elite list of winners who have won the South African Triple Crown including: Horse Chestnut (1999), Louis The King (2014) and Abashiri (2016).

Premier’s Champion Challenge – Turffontein (May)

The Grade 1 handicap race is the second richest on the South African calendar worth R $4 million run over 2000 metres.

It attracts the best horses in the country chasing victory on one of the biggest race days of the year at Turffontein.

Vodacom Durban July – Greyville (July)

First run in 1897 the Durban July is widely acknowledged as the greatest horse race in Africa’s racing calendar.

Originally run over 1600 metres the handicap race is now over 2200 metres at Greyville with a capacity field of 18 runners. It attracts a capacity crowd of 50,000 racegoers.

It is the pinnacle event for trainers, jockeys, and owners with only six horses having won the race on two occasions.

The Justin Snaith-trained Do It Again was the last horse to do so winning in 2018 and 2019. Snaith has trained the winner on five occasions and is aiming to surpass Syd Laird who has a record seven July winners.

Summer Cup – Turffontein (November)

Known as the “People’s race” the Summer Cup has been run since 1887 and is one of the most prestigious races on the calendar.

The race day itself is a huge celebration and the only meeting which features a half-time show, bringing together hundreds of performers to entertain the crowd for 20 minutes before the main race.

The time and name changed at various points over the years, but Phumelela reintroduced it to run its traditional slot back in 1999.

South African Racing FAQs

When does racing in South Africa start?

Racing in South Africa is all year round, racing 364 days a year.

What is the richest race in South Africa?

The Cape Met (2000m) is a weight-for-age race with the richest prize money in South Africa, run at Kenilworth in late January worth R $5,000,000. The Durban July (2200m) is worth R 4.25 million run at Greyville in early July.

When is the South African racing season?

There are Grade 1 races throughout the year from January to December starting with the Queen’s Plate (January 9) and finishing with Cape Guineas (December 18) both at Kenilworth.

When is the Champions Season in South Africa?

The Champions Season runs from May to July with a variety of feature races run at Greyville and Scottsville.

Do Australian trained horses run in South Africa?

Australian-trained horses don’t generally compete in South Africa.

How can I watch South African racing live?

South Africa racing can be watched in Australia on Sky Racing (Foxtel channel 526 & 527). It can be streamed via the Sky Racing Active App and the TAB app.
